instruction: Can Raman spectroscopy (RS) be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for detecting the Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation in unprocessed glioma biopsies?
Output: Raman spectroscopy (RS) can be considered a superior method compared to traditional methods for detecting the Isocitrate dehydrogenase (IDH) mutation in unprocessed glioma biopsies. The past study found that RS had an accuracy and precision of 87% in distinguishing between IDH-mutated and IDH-wild-type tumors. Additionally, RS showed optimal accuracy and precision in discriminating IDH-mutated glioma from IDH-wild-type tumors ex-vivo onto fresh surgical specimens. This suggests that RS has great potential as a minimally invasive optical technique for intraoperative diagnosis and can accurately characterize the mutational status of IDH in unprocessed glioma samples.
